description: From Middle English dropesie, idropesie, from Old French idropsie, ydropisie, from Latin hydropisis, from Ancient Greek ὕδρωψ (húdrōps), from ὕδωρ (húdōr, “water”). Doublet of hydropsy and hydrops.

examples: Your sacred Majesty, he has the dropsy;—We shall find pints of hydatids in’s liver,He has not half an inch of wholesome fatUpon his carious ribs—
